concept.title: About this article
concept.shortdesc: Structured documents can provide a simple and reliable way to write and manage policy and procedure documents.

conbody.p: This article is written for someone writing or managing policy and procedure documents, and standards documents of any kind. (I will use these terms interchangeably.)

Can the technology and technique called DITA help? Well, perhaps. There are some very real advantages to trying DITA for this purpose, and some challenges. If you are involved in managing standards, I think it could be well worth trying.
DITA is actually designed as a general purpose information interchange format. It is probably the most future-proof format you can write documents in, and is a safe format for long-lived documents.

The existing literature on DITA seems to be written by
originators and implementators of the DITA specification, who are perhaps not aware of the specific needs of standards authors
consultants of various kinds, who might quite naturally emphasise some of the benefits and less of the disadvantages, and who also might try to solve unnecessary technical problems
technical writers in the specific fields of product documentation and, more especially, computer software documentation. This is a quite different genre from standards. These writers might be focused on less relevant techniques when applied specifically to standards.

Most reference works to DITA have a slant towards localisation and translation costs. Localisation and translation isn’t usually of interest when writing policy and procedure documents. Other DITA reference works expect the content to be in the genre of product information, where DITA’s core support and communities seems to reside.
This article argues the case for using DITA for standards. It doesn't contain many technical details, because these are available elsewhere by people far better qualified than me.

It was written in DITA using an XML editor called oXygen Author. It was easy to write using DITA. Let's explore how DITA might, or might not help you to write policy and procedure standards documents.
